text.text: What is Equitable Resilience?

The capacity for communities to withstand, adapt, transform in the face of climate change and disasters in ways that are culturally appropriate, participatory, and responsive to social vulnerabilities to disasters and climate change, and to the potentially unequal benefits and burdens of adaptation and resilience interventions (Glossary)

It is a form of social-environmental resilience that considers differentiated access to knowledge, power, and resources [1]. The specifics depend on locally relevant hazard(s), social vulnerability, equity, and social, built, and natural environment systems (Figure 1). It entails attention to the
process
of how to carry out resilience planning, as well as the
content
of such plans [2].
Figure 1. Factors that affect the achievement of equitable resilience for a community
Why does it matter?

The impacts of climate change and disasters are not experienced evenly within and across communities. Social vulnerabilities affect how distinct populations and social groups experience these hazards (e.g. elderly, youth; persons with disabilities; unhoused individuals; low-income households; Black, Indigenous, and other persons of color; LGBTQIA+). They also affect who bears disproportionate impacts and cascading social, financial, health, and cultural consequences [3, 4].

Resilience, hazard mitigation, and climate change adaptations run the risk of make social and environmental inequalities worse. This can occur if historically marginalized groups are not listened to in planning. It can also occur if resilience solutions do not specifically attempt to identify and rectify inequalities.
How can ERB help
The Equitable Resilience Builder (ERB) offers a guided process to support local resilience practitioners in integrating equitable resilience into planning (Figure 2).
Figure 2. The ERB Process

A core team uses it to plan collaborative workshops that use local knowledge and other data to assess current conditions and identify actions to target efforts in strengthening resilience in a fair and just way. Communities can benefit in 4 ways:
A stronger network of community organizations and agencies to share information and resources.
Facilitation guides for holding workshops in trauma-informed ways
Activity guides for soliciting community perspectives
Local knowledge is valued and utilized alongside scientific data
Data and maps on hazards, equity, and resilient community systems
Locally meaningful and measurable indicators to measure change in social, built, and natural environment systems
A set of actions and next steps
Ongoing monitoring for change
